abstract: Editorial holds that the Obama administration memo seeking legal justification for killing American-born radical Muslim cleric Anwar al-Awlaki is an insufficient foundation for a momentous decision by the government to kill one of its own citizens; charges that the administration seems to know that anti-terrorist operations do not escape the rule of law, and suggests that its case would be far stronger if it would simply acknowledge as much.
snippet: The government’s legal memo on Anwar al-Awlaki’s death is a step, but not enough for a momentous decision to kill one of its own citizens.
lead_paragraph: The government’s legal memo on Anwar al-Awlaki’s death is a step, but not enough for a momentous decision to kill one of its own citizens.

headline.main: Justifying the Killing of an American
headline.print_headline: Justifying the Killing of an American: The government’s legal memo on Anwar al-Awlaki’s death is a step, but not enough of one
headline.seo: Justifying the Killing of an American
